abstract: Alan D. Schwartz, the former chief of Bear Stearns when it collapsed in 2008 and was absorbed by JPMorgan Chase, told Andrew Ross Sorkin that a proposed $11 billion settlement with the Justice Department “doesn’t feel like it makes sense, but it makes good headlines.”
snippet: Alan D. Schwartz, the former chief of Bear Stearns when it collapsed in 2008 and was absorbed by JPMorgan Chase, told Andrew Ross Sorkin that a proposed $11 billion settlement with the Justice Department “doesn’t feel like it makes sense, but it m...
lead_paragraph: Alan D. Schwartz, the former chief of Bear Stearns when it collapsed in 2008 and was absorbed by JPMorgan Chase, told Andrew Ross Sorkin that a proposed $11 billion settlement with the Justice Department “doesn’t feel like it makes sense, but it makes good headlines.”

headline.main: Ex-Bear Stearns Chief Questions JPMorgan’s Mortgage Deal

abstract: The unknowable vagaries of time can complicate the appraisal of the assets in an estate — and yet appraise you must, or risk incurring penalties from the I.R.S.
snippet: The unknowable vagaries of time can complicate the appraisal of the assets in an estate — and yet appraise you must, or risk incurring penalties from the I.R.S.
lead_paragraph: MICHAEL JACKSON and J. D. Salinger would seem to have had little in common beyond being famous, reclusive (to different degrees) and the subject of much speculation about their personal lives. But in death the King of Pop and the author of “The Catcher in the Rye” have become sources of fascination and speculation among estate lawyers and the people charged with putting a price on hard-to-value assets, like royalties that continue paying after they are gone.

headline.main: Putting an Estate Value on the Assets Unique to You
headline.print_headline: Putting an Estate Value on the Assets Unique to You
